div.p:
I beg leave
to enclose another
of my lame
specimens. It
floats on the
water of the
Zambesi and
is very pretty.
It has no root in
the soil but
seems quite
content with
the water. Tthis
has preserved
its appearance
but is much
shrivelled. A
water plant
called by the
Portuguese Alfacinya
"lettuce" from its
resemblance to
that plant also
floats on the water
and great quantities
come down a
river called Shire into the
Zambesi. It is
said quite to
obstruct the
navigation. It is
on that account
I mention it in the
book. I saw it
at Oxford but the
name has escaped
me. It is like a
little cabbage-
Another plant appeared
at the same time
which I don't trouble
you with but
only mention
it as to me a
curiosity. It
is called Njefu
and has a leafe
of this size & shape
at there is
a nut which
Sebituane the
chief liked so
much he
made it a
part of the tribute
from the tribes
he subjected.
I liked those I
eat and they
were floating
in company
with the Alfacinya.
If you can
give me the
proper name
of the last
I shall feel obliged
but do not
I pray you
spend much
time on the subject. Many
and hearty thanks
for your notes
all of which
came duly to
hand. As also
the notes from
Mr Westwood
for which I am
very thankful.

Please present
my kindest
salutations to
Mrs H& believe
me Most truly.
